articles.title: TC39 Advances 10+ ECMAScript Proposals
articles.description: The architects behind the development of the ECMAScript / JavaScript spec got together again this week (you can see them in this tweet) and they had a packed agenda. Import attributes, Iterator helpers, Promise.try and Regexp modifiers all made it to stage 4, and more besides.
articles.author: Sarah Gooding (Socket)

articles.title: ü¶ñ¬†Announcing Deno 2
articles.description: A huge release for the ‚Äúwhat if I reinvented Node again from scratch?‚Äù runtime. Backwards compatibility with Node is a headline feature, but there‚Äôs a lot more baked in. Best, though, is the ‚ñ∂Ô∏è epic ‚ÄòAnnouncing Deno 2‚Äô video. After a slightly bombastic opener, Ryan presents a fantastic ‚Äòkeynote‚Äô style tour of everything Deno has to offer ‚Äì I enjoyed watching it.
articles.author: Dahl, Belder, Iwa≈Ñczuk and Jiang

articles.title: Announcing TypeScript 5.7 Beta
articles.description: The newest TypeScript is on the way. As always, a true laundry list of enhancements and new features, but the path rewriting for relative paths is a particularly welcome addition, enabling easy rewrites of .ts imports into .js at compile time.
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: Building a Local Single-Page App with htmx
articles.description: If you have a reasonably simple app to build, using a large framework is probably going to be overkill. htmx to the rescue! Jake presents an easily followed practical tutorial packed with code.
articles.author: Jake Lazaroff

articles.title: Build a Static RSS Reader To Fight Your Inner FOMO
articles.description: The theme of lightweight JavaScript apps continues with a look at creating a basic RSS feed reader, that updates once a day, with Astro.
articles.author: Karin Hendrikse

articles.title: Node vs Bun: No Backend Performance Difference?
articles.description: You can always trust a benchmark to ruffle some feathers, often over the methodology rather than the result. This is no exception, but interesting nonetheless.
articles.author: Evert Heylen

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Building a Tic-Tac-Toe Game in TypeScript Types
articles.description: One of those videos I enjoyed simply so I don‚Äôt ever feel tempted to try it myself.
articles.author: Typed Rocks

articles.title: DOCX 9.0: Generate Word .docx Files from JavaScript
articles.description: The code to lay out documents is verbose but there‚Äôs a lot of functionality baked in and there aren‚Äôt many other options for this task. Here‚Äôs a CodePen-based example to give you an idea. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Dolan Miu

articles.title: TinyJS: A Lightweight Way to Work with DOM Elements
articles.description: Lighter than querySelector and friends, you ask? Not in file size, but certainly in code weight. TinyJS offers a jQuery-esque syntax for element selection, adding properties to elements, and more.
articles.author: Victor Ribeiro

articles.title: SVGuitar 2.4: Create SVG-Based Guitar Chord Charts
articles.description: Dynamically generate chord charts / fingerings in the browser. You can experiment with it in this live demo.
articles.author: Raphael Voellmy

articles.title: Free Public APIs: A Collection of Free Public APIs for Developers
articles.description: Categorized and searchable, these are tested daily by bots so if any API is taken down or moved behind a paywall, it's removed from the site.
articles.author: Nick Schneeberger

articles.title: TutorialKit 1.0: Create Interactive Coding Tutorials
articles.description: StackBlitz‚Äôs framework for creating interactive coding tutorials, perhaps as a way to boost the adoption of your own libraries or design system. v1.0 marks TutorialKit as stable.
articles.author: StackBlitz

articles.title: Jeasx: The Ease of JSX with the Power of SSR
articles.description: A new server side rendering framework built on top of JSX and Fastify.
articles.author: Maik Jablonski

articles.title: ip-address 10.0: Library for Parsing and Manipulating IP Addresses
articles.description: Works with both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses.
articles.author: Beau Gunderson

articles.description: Ian Grunert writes about work done to (re)enable JavaScriptCore's JIT mechanisms on Windows. This is particularly good news for Bun users.
Did you know MySQL 9.0 now natively supports JavaScript stored routines?
üá∫üá∏ The next JSNation event is taking place in a hybrid form both remotely and in New York City this November 18 and 21. Some fantastic speakers await.
Tenno is an interesting online Markdown editor that supports adding spreadsheet-like cells that can be populated by JavaScript.
üïπÔ∏è The winners of the latest js13kGames game jam have been announced. It's amazing what people have managed to achieve in just 13KB.

Bun v1.1.30 ‚Äì Now includes experimental CSS parsing and bundling, as well as a bun publish to publish npm packages, a la npm publish. You can also compile code to bytecode to speed up startup times.
Node.js v20.18.0 (LTS) ‚Äì Now with network inspection support.
React Native Storybook 8.3 ‚Äì React Native support in the popular component workshop finally gets fully up to speed.
Rsdoctor 0.4 ‚Äì Tool for analyzing the Rspack / Webpack build process.
ESLint 9.12.0, Electron.js 32.2, Ember 5.12

articles.title: CSS Nesting Improves with CSSNestedDeclarations
articles.description: CSSNestedDeclarations is a new, CSS Working Group approved interface to fix some quirks of CSS nesting, such as declarations that come after style rules confusingly shifting up. It‚Äôs in Chrome from v130, and testing is underway in Firefox and Safari. Bramus shares a quick behind-the-scenes here but in short: "This means that CSS nesting got a whole lot better as of Chrome 130."
articles.author: Bramus Van Damme (Google)

articles.title: Uh-oh, .io?¬†The Disappearance of an Internet Domain?
articles.description: The British government recently announced it was transferring sovereignty of the Chagos Islands to Mauritius. But how can geopolitics alter digital infrastructure? The decision may result in the loss of one of the tech and gaming industry‚Äôs much-loved (though problematic) top-level domains: .io.
articles.author: Gareth Edwards

articles.title: "Automattic is Doing Open Source Dirty"
articles.description: DHH (of Ruby on Rails fame) chimes in on the ongoing WordPress saga, which seems to show no sign of abating soon. He states a concern ‚Äúabout the integrity of open source licenses‚Äù, adding that such ‚Äúintegrity is under direct assault by Automattic‚Äôs grotesque claim for WP Engine‚Äôs revenues‚Äù. Matt Mullenweg of WordPress replied on X.
articles.author: David Heinemeier Hansson

articles.title: Searching for a New CSS Logo
articles.description: Did you know that there's an active, ongoing search for a logo to help visualize all things CSS and ‚Äúaid in the marketing and promotion of the new CSS era‚Äù? There‚Äôs a bunch of discussion and suggested designs being shared in the CSS-Next repo.
articles.author: Ryan Trimble

articles.title: Firefox 131 'Supercharges' CSS Variables Debugging
articles.description: Version 131 of Mozilla‚Äôs browser was released last week adding notable improvements to debugging CSS variables along with other Inspector improvements.
articles.author: Nicolas Chevobbe

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†State Queries
articles.description: Una and Adam discuss a future web capability that builds on container queries: state queries. This upcoming feature will, for example, be able to detect if a container is overflowing, when an element is scroll snapped, and when an element is stuck from position: sticky.
articles.author: Chrome for Developers

articles.title: Plain Vanilla: A Tutorial Website for Plain Vanilla Web Development
articles.description: The incentive behind this project is to teach building complex and dynamic apps without complex tools ‚Äì just HTML, CSS, and JS, using modern features like Web Components, hash-based routing, etc.
articles.author: Joeri Sebrechts

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Web Components: Little Bits
articles.description: In this ~20 minute video from the recent State of the Browser conference, David shares how he is using Web Components to help develop complex design systems as well as custom open-source tools. More videos from the event are available too.
articles.author: David Darnes

articles.title: Building a Robust Frontend with Progressive Enhancement
articles.description: The UK government website is a rare and successful example of running a huge, behemoth of a site, with strong, robust systems and sound user experience considerations. Here, they touch upon how progressive enhancement plays a crucial role in making things tick.
articles.author: UK Government

articles.title: player.style: Video & Audio Player Themes for Every Web Player &¬†Framework
articles.description: A collection of well-presented, good looking web component media players (...and one that looks like how you remember WinAmp). Lots of customization options and easy copy and paste results too.
articles.author: Mux

articles.title: PlaceholderJS: Ridiculously Simple and Lightweight Placeholders
articles.description: Available for use via a CDN or as a React component, these are simple SVG-based placeholders that you can customize (size, color, background, etc.) using URL or component parameters.
articles.author: Owen Bick

articles.title: Statichunt: A Directory of 3900+ Composable Themes, Templates & Tools for Static Site Generators
articles.description: An organized collection of tools that you can filter using categories like Astro, Hugo, Gatsby, Eleventy, Jekyll, etc., as well as framework keywords like Tailwind, Bootstrap, Bulma, etc.
articles.author: ZEON STUDIO

articles.title: qrframe: A Library to Generate 'Pretty' QR¬†Codes
articles.description: An odd project as the QR codes generated aren‚Äôt always guaranteed to scan reliably, but if you can generate one that does, they're very striking. Could be useful for branding/fun use cases. You can play around with a live demo here.
articles.author: Kyle Zheng
